title: Netania Davrath
text:
Netania Davrath (Нетания Доврат) (12 August 193111 April 1987) was a Ukrainian-born Israeli <a href="soprano">soprano</a> <a href="opera">opera</a> and concert singer.
Early life and study.
In 1948, Davrath moved to Israel with her family. There, she studied in Jerusalem with Edith Boroschek. She subsequently studied in <a href="D%C3%BCsseldorf">Düsseldorf</a> and later at the <a href="Juilliard%20School">Juilliard School</a> in New York with <a href="Jennie%20Tourel">Jennie Tourel</a>, as well as in Italy.
Career.
Davrath's repertoire included both opera and concert pieces. She collaborated with conductors <a href="Leonard%20Bernstein">Leonard Bernstein</a>, <a href="John%20Barbirolli">John Barbirolli</a>, <a href="Leopold%20Stokowski">Leopold Stokowski</a> and <a href="Zubin%20Mehta">Zubin Mehta</a> and several orchestras: the <a href="New%20York%20Philharmonic">New York Philharmonic</a>, <a href="Chicago%20Symphony%20Orchestra">Chicago Symphony Orchestra</a>, <a href="London%20Philharmonic">London Philharmonic</a>, <a href="Israel%20Philharmonic">Israel Philharmonic</a>, <a href="Lyric%20Opera%20of%20Chicago">Lyric Opera of Chicago</a>, and <a href="Opera%20Boston">Opera Boston</a> among others. She recorded ten discs under the <a href="Vanguard%20Classics">Vanguard Classics</a> label. Davrath was fluent in eight languages.
Her childhood years may have influenced her attraction to folk music – first in her native country <a href="Ukraine">Ukraine</a> (then part of the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a>), then later in Israel. These influences are reflected in her performance style; a delicate tone, clarity of enunciation, and agility. Her early recording of <a href="Joseph%20Canteloube">Joseph Canteloube</a>'s "<a href="Chants%20d%27Auvergne">Chants d'Auvergne</a>" is considered by many to be unsurpassed.
